guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Water bottles
  • Ruler
  • Rubber bands
  • Chopsticks
  • Paper clips
Tools
  • Needlenose pliers
  • Scissors

lines.text: To see the original Howtoons cartoon full-size, click on the "View huge" link at the top left of this image (mouse over it and you'll see the link).
lines.text_raw: To see the original Howtoons cartoon full-size, click on the "View huge" link at the top left of this image (mouse over it and you'll see the link).

lines.text: Drill a hole in the bottom of your bottle.
lines.text_raw: Drill a hole in the bottom of your bottle.

lines.text: Using chopsticks, feed a paper clip through.
lines.text_raw: Using chopsticks, feed a paper clip through.

lines.text: Hook paper clip into second hole for stability.
lines.text_raw: Hook paper clip into second hole for stability.

lines.text: Use chopsticks to hook the rubber band to the paper clip.
lines.text_raw: Use chopsticks to hook the rubber band to the paper clip.

lines.text: Connect ruler stabilizer fins with 2 rubber bands.
lines.text_raw: Connect ruler stabilizer fins with 2 rubber bands.

lines.text: NOTE: Why you need stabilizer fins: Without fins, prop and bottle both spin in opposite directions. With stabilizing fins, the prop spins and the bottle moves forward.
lines.text_raw: NOTE: Why you need stabilizer fins: Without fins, prop and bottle both spin in opposite directions. With stabilizing fins, the prop spins and the bottle moves forward.

lines.text: Crush, then cut a bottle in half.
lines.text_raw: Crush, then cut a bottle in half.

lines.text: Trim around the bottom, and cut through the middle of each high and low point.
lines.text_raw: Trim around the bottom, and cut through the middle of each high and low point.

lines.text: Drill a hole in the bottle cap.
lines.text_raw: Drill a hole in the bottle cap.

lines.text: Straighten paper clip, and feed through bottle cap then through propeller's center hole. Bend a hook into second hole.
lines.text_raw: Straighten paper clip, and feed through bottle cap then through propeller's center hole. Bend a hook into second hole.

lines.text: Attach loose end of rubber band to paper clip hook.
lines.text_raw: Attach loose end of rubber band to paper clip hook.

lines.text: With lots of air inside, the sub has positive buoyancy and will rise under water or float on top.
lines.text_raw: With lots of air inside, the sub has positive buoyancy and will rise under water or float on top.

lines.text: With just enough air inside, the sub has neutral buoyancy and will stay level under water.
lines.text_raw: With just enough air inside, the sub has neutral buoyancy and will stay level under water.

lines.text: With little or no air inside, the sub has negative buoyancy and will sink under water.
lines.text_raw: With little or no air inside, the sub has negative buoyancy and will sink under water.

guide.summary: Make a simple, self-propelled submarine out of soda bottles and other household items.
guide.title: Soda Bottle Submarine
